docs.lead_paragraph: On her fourth day as a teacher, Donna Moffett would not -- could not -- stop smiling. Never mind that only 8 of her 21 first graders had shown up on time to follow her, ducklinglike, from the schoolyard to her muggy second-floor classroom at Public School 92 in Brooklyn. Or that one little boy, with rumpled curls and a sullen gaze, rolled his eyes and disparaged her every move.

headline.main: MS. MOFFETT'S FIRST YEAR/Learning to Teach; A Novice's Hard Lesson: Bringing Order to a Class

docs.abstract: First of series of articles following former legal secretary Donna Moffett, one of 320 'teaching fellows' recruited by New York City to fill chronic vacancies in city's most troubled public schools: Ms Moffett's First Year: Learning to Teach; Moffett, with only crash course in teaching and eight hours of certification exams, has been assigned to PS 92 in Flatbush, Brooklyn, school where nearly three-quarters of students read below grade level; she is under tremendous pressure to start her 21 first graders reading and writing, and to prepare them for tests they will face in later grades; in her first days as novice teacher, Moffett finds herself spending far more time on 'classroom management,' teaching students classroom rules, than on lessons; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration is expected to decide by Saturday whether it will approve the abortion pill, known as mifepristone or RU-486, for sale in the United States. It would be the first alternative to surgical abortion approved here. The drug allows women to terminate pregnancy within seven weeks of their last menstrual period. It has been sold in Europe and elsewhere in the world for more than a decade, and an F.D.A. advisory committee has recommended approving the drug for this country. The agency usually accepts such recommendations.

headline.main: F.D.A.'s Decision on Whether to Permit Sale of Abortion Pill Is Expected Soon

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration is expected to decide by Sept 30 whether it will approve abortion pill known as mifepristone or RU-486, for sale in United States; it would be first alternative to surgical abortion approved in country; action on drug has been stalled by abortion politics (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ZEN is an upfront influence at the office of ZoZa, a new fashion company set for its Web debut in mid-October. Shoes are to be removed at the entrance and placed in cabinets. A hefty Chinese gong stands ready to call meetings, and there's a large empty swath of carpet for the staff's morning yoga classes. ZoZa's high-tech stretchy clothes feature a symbol from the I Ching that means both ''contemplation'' and ''mountain.'' Floating across the screen at www.zoza.com will be a mini-swirl of snowflakes; click on it for a kernel of Zen wisdom, like, ''Be present, not tense.''

headline.main: About to Hatch Their Third Republic
headline.kicker: AT HOME WITH/MEL AND PATRICIA ZIEGLER

docs.abstract: Mel and Patricia Ziegler, who launched and later sold Banana Republic, have a new and very different project, ZoZa, clothing company whose designs will be based on their domestic Zen power base; business will be on the Web at first, with the first store opening later in Mill Valley, Calif, where couple live; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Oh, sure, some women are embarrassed for their sex this week. But those women are wimps. I feel a certain undeniable pride that women have taken control of the two great male preserves of America -- politics and sports -- and ruined them.
docs.abstract: Maureen Dowd Op-Ed column sees politicians and television executives packaging presidential race and Olympics to appeal to what they see as women's desire to be cuddled (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In 1983, the morning sickness drug Bendectin was removed from the market amid a barrage of lawsuits claiming that it caused birth defects. Now, in what medical and legal experts say is a highly unusual reversal of fortune, it may well be brought back. A small privately held Canadian company, Duchesnay Inc., is working with the Food and Drug Administration to gain permission to market a generic version of Bendectin, which it calls Diclectin. Duchesnay is already selling the drug, its only product, in Canada, labeling and marketing it specifically for pregnant women.

docs.lead_paragraph: NATURAL BLONDE/A Memoir By Liz Smith Illustrated. 460 pages. Hyperion. $25.95. FOUR BLONDES By Candace Bushnell 245 pages. Atlantic Monthly Press. $24. There are pictures of Mary Elizabeth Smith throughout her memoir, and she seldom looks the same twice. That chameleon quality has been all-important to her life and career. She wrote for Sports Illustrated and Cosmopolitan simultaneously. She morphed from the child her father called ''my best boy'' to flirty ingenue. She took potshots in print at Frank Sinatra but melted into goo when courted by the singer. (''I loved him. I had a feeling for what it would be like to be in his strong and capable arms.'') And throughout it all Liz Smith was in it for the fun.

headline.main: The Fair-Haired Life, From Two Points of View

docs.lead_paragraph: When I was a child I did not know that the circus had an intermission. The moment the break came in the show, my mother would stand up and say, ''Well, wasn't that wonderful?'' and sweep us toward the exit of Madison Square Garden faster than you could say ''Ringling, Barnum and Bailey.'' She was willing to do her duty to entertain the children, but like many parents, she had her limits. My siblings and I returned home sticky from cotton candy, blissfully unaware that we had missed half the show.

headline.main: When Baby Makes Three, It Begins. When Does It End?

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Anne E. Dyson, a pediatrician known for her philanthropy in the field of children's welfare, died yesterday at her home in Millbrook, N.Y. She was 52. Dr. Dyson died after a yearlong struggle with breast cancer, according to a statement from the Dyson Foundation, a family philanthropy.

headline.main: Dr. Anne Dyson, 52, Educator, Pediatrician and Philanthropist

docs.lead_paragraph: New evidence from Hawaii and Missouri indicates that gonorrhea is becoming resistant to a wider variety of antibiotics, federal health officials said yesterday. Because of the findings, the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta issued new recommendations for doctors in prescribing antibiotics for gonorrhea. The agency also urged patients to discuss recent travels with their doctors when gonorrhea was suspected.

docs.lead_paragraph: Hollywood could learn a thing or two about how to be truthful and lighthearted at the same time from Nisha Ganatra's perky little comedy ''Chutney Popcorn.'' The story of an Indian-American lesbian who impulsively decides to have a baby for her married, infertile older sister carries off the tricky feat of being wisecracking one minute and serious the next while staying true to its characters and sustaining a jovial easygoing tone. Here is one comedy that actually earns its mostly happy ending.

headline.main: And Baby Makes Two, For Now

docs.abstract: Stephen Holden reviews movie Chutney Popcorn, directed by Nisha Ganatra; she also co-stars with Jill Hennessy and Madhur Jaffrey (M)
